I have a very long background and

this talk isn't a sales pitch for Modio.

need a justification to be able to do
that. Um, Modio commissioned some some
simple research into the impact that
mods have on games that add support for
it. if you need that information to kind
of take back to your studio to justify
it. So, on average, games with UGC make
more money. Um, you can see that um, by
year five, games with mod support had a
23% advantage in revenue over those
without mod support. And games with mod
support have greater retention. By year
2, they had a 64% advantage in
concurrent user accounts, and that was
up to 90% by year five. Generally, we
don't see mods impacting DLC sales if
that's a concern. There are many games
on Steam that have seen their DLC sales
increase as a result from engagement in
UGC. Part of that is some clever
implementation of mod support where, you

let's talk about the existing solutions.
There's three that I kind of want to
touch on. The first one is simple UGC.
Um, this is a project and plugin that
originated from Robo Recall, uh, which
was a commercial VR game that Epic ship

which is a like third party
communitydriven injectable lure C++, um,
blueprint system that basically injects
and silos loads binaries to add that mod

what I call the just hack it together
group of people which basically use
community tools to reverse engineer your
your content uh and then use the
engine's pack loading priority and
patching system to be able to get that
content loaded in game. So a couple of
quick pros and cons for each of these.
Simple UGC is a proven structure. If
you're not familiar with how it works,
it has what they call an actor
replaceable component. You put that
component onto an actor to indicate what
it can be indicate that it can be
replaced by something that someone else
has created. They create a mod. you
create a mapping to say I want this
actor to replace this actor on startup
it gets put into a UGC registry and then
anytime you spawn that class you just
look for any like overridable actor
that's part of that um so it's kind of
fairly easy to reason about you have a
lot of good control over exactly what
can be replaced it includes really good
built-in mod templates and packaging
tools um that are very creative friendly
you can make it work on consoles but it
doesn't work out of the box because it
uses that engine startup loading
behavior on the cons there's no U5
support you could upgrade it it's not
really that much friction Um, and that
class stopping model basically anytime
you call spawn you have to look up a
class replacement for something which is
a lot of overhead or you've got to
modify the end spawn method to do it. So
it's potentially not really that
scalable for like a really rich kind of
support.
Uss is no lift for your studio because

Unreal content reverse engineering to

Um, LU is very flexible. Developers are

also means it won't work on platforms

for SS and integrate into your game as a

because the community generates the

Same again with the Just Hack Together

So why would you want to build it

it can be more fully integrated into

as a result, because you don't have to

So pack files way of bunding content for
a target platform from the cooking
process and when you cook content it's
optimized for that specific target
platform which means that um that pack
file can't be loaded by uh another
platform.
This is a slight oversimplification for
how pack files are loaded. There is like
a more complicated internal priority
system, but loosely speaking, any pack
file that ends with underscorep is a
patch pack file that's prioritized for
loading by the engine. And then
basically the engine will start at the
root packs folder. Uh it'll iterate
through all of the pack file chunks that
are in there and then all the subfolders
and then load all of that content
loosely in the pack alphabetical lawyer.
And the reason that that means that
those just hack it together crew can
override content is because anything
that's looked at later patches over an
earlier looked at asset. So as an
example, if packchunk zero and pack
chunk one both have an asset at game/c
character u assasset, the one in pack
chunk one takes priority.
Um so just to talk about the differences
between pack and IO store. So, if you're
cooking without IO store, which was the
way in Unreal 4, you just get a single
pack file per chunk, this is loaded by
something called the event-driven
loader, otherwise known as the EDL,
which essentially is just a simplified
file system that you can iterate through
really easily and reference files inside
of. Uh, it is a legacy pathway. It's no
longer updated in the engine. It's
essentially maintained to facilitate
migration for titles coming from Unreal
Engine 4. The default since Unreal
Engine 5 is the IO store. Um you might
have heard a few other people talking
about the Zen loader or Zen storage. Um
and Zen is basically the entire system
that the IO store uses for a lot of its
content dispatching. It produces three
pack file three files per chunk. A pack
file which is for loose inly access
files like asset registry and
localization. A UKcast file, a content
addressable store which holds the actual
cooked content and a talk file table of
contents which is basically a lookup for
the content within the corresponding CS
file.
You can't actually mix these either. So
if your game is cooked with IO store,
you can't load a pack file that's cooked
with nonIO store if that's what your
your modders are doing. Um, so it's kind
of important to understand these. You
should always be shipping with IO store
turned on. It is more performance. It's
the default pathway. It's maintained and
updated, optimized for streaming and all
those new systems like you know Zen
streaming, Zen storage, etc. Um, so all
this talk is going to assume that you're
using IO store uh in your game.

to download patches for

asset. Um so overriding this entry is

is something that we tried. Um it does
work for some things. It doesn't work
for other things. Um basically the gist
of core redirects is that it's a system
that the engine has is you want to
redirect a reference of this asset or
class or whatever to this one. Um, that
doesn't work for anything that has a CDO
because the uh redirectctors are
resolved at CDIO time, which basically
happens when the engine starts up. So,
you can't like redirect a character
class to another character class because
the engine would have already resolved
that redirector when it when it
launched. But you could do it for a
texture in a map because if you want to
change a stop sign to a giveway sign,
um, you can you could do that because
that hadn't actually been loaded and
that redirector hasn't actually been

It's what Unreal is designed to do. um

Um so some final thoughts. Um these are
things that I could spend like a long
time talking about um but you know don't
have substantial amount of time to do
it. If you're going to release a public
editor um for your game um you do need a
agreement with Epic. Um so speak to your
Epic rep if you do want to ship a custom
editor. Um, ensure that you strip all of
your source code out. Please do not ship
your game source code. You can do binary
only builds of the editor uh and of the
engine that content creators can use.
Um, you can ship all of your assets and
those sort of things. Um, and make sure
that you do ship out your releases for
content creators to cook their content
from. Uh, we just had 2 go live
overnight with their mod kit. It is 700
gig, so they can get quite large. Um,
but they've basically provided all of
their content, their scripting
languages, all those sort of things for
content creators to be able to create
some pretty awesome stuff. Uh, console
tools are under NDA, so you cannot
distribute those. So, if you are
interested in being able to do mods on
consoles, you will need to use either
some sort of cloud cooking service. We
have one at Mod.io. Um, or um, you might
want to produce and prepare that content
offline yourself. Um, so we got some
studios who will basically manually
curate that content. Um, they will they
will reach out to the content creators,
say, "We love your mod. We want it to go
on console." They'll build that
relationship, get the source files, cook
them internally, and make them available
to console players. Totally valid
approach because most console holders do
require some form of moderation system
before content goes live. So, you're
going to have to go through reviewing
that content anyway. They want safety on
their platforms. The one thing I will
mention with the console holders though
is that they're way more receptive now

that's changed a fair bit and we've seen

you know, a lot of those kind of, you

put on put on their their platforms and,
you know, the hoops you had to jump

as they're getting familiar with with
this whole concept of of mods being on
